The "San Fernando II" communal bank is made up of ten members, seven women and three men who are all mothers and fathers responsible for twenty children. All adults, they are natives of El Sauce a place which is located in the northern part of the region. They are hard-working and responsible and have the desire to excel personally. In their spare time they like to be in the company of their children. Today they are fighting day by day to provide their children with economic stability, etc.

Thanks to her desire to get ahead, Modesta is coordinator of this group. She has a grocery store, a small shop which is located in her house. She sells consumable goods in small quantities. She sells items such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs detergent, juices, biscuits, etc. She spends twelve hours a day selling her products. The objective of the loan is to stock her store and obtain higher income in the near future.

The "San Fernando II" communal bank is grateful for the support the Kiva lenders provide to people of low resources and poor countries like Nicaragua so they can have a dignified means of work.

loans.use: to buy food products like rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, detergents, juices, biscuits, etc.

loans.name: Yehowa No Group

texts.en: This group is made up of four members who live in the same neighborhood and have been together for many years. They belong to a group called 'Yehowa no' and are into the sale of smoked fish. Elizabeth (standing on the left in the photo) is the featured borrower of the group. She is an elementary school leaver and has been selling smoked fish door-to-door for 10 years now. She enjoys doing this job because it is profitable and has earned her many customers. Together with her friends, the group will need a total of GHS 2,400 to buy more fish to sell to their regular customers in order to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to her regular customers in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Galilea Group

texts.es:
Galilea es el nombre de un grupo integrado por personas alegres y trabajadoras provenientes de una comunidad tranquila, pequeña y rodeada de vegetación. Dicho nombre fue elegido por sus miembros ya que es el mismo de una pequeña niña, hija de una integrante. Cabe mencionar que tienen un gran apego a sus tradiciones tanto religiosas como populares y los días de fiesta conviven los unos con los otros de manera amigable e incluso fraternal. 
   A Yolanda todos le llaman de cariño Yola ya que la aprecian y tienen confianza en ella por su carácter amable y seguro. Es madre de dos hijas, una de ellas Galilea, quienes estudian la educación primaria y son su gran motor para continuar adelante. Desde hace 12 años se ha dedicado al comercio; inicialmente vendía cinturones pero con el tiempo encontró en los artículos de limpieza ingresos más favorables y desde entonces no ha parado. Entre ella y su esposo se coordinan para vender, adquirir mercancía y cuidar de sus pequeñas por quienes realizan todo el esfuerzo; "Generalmente viajamos algunos días para obtener ganancias y regresamos poco después a descansar y pasar tiempo con nuestras hijas" comentó. 
   Una de las temporadas en que mayores ganancias obtienen es la de fin de año ya que muchas personas buscan artículos para realizar la cena de navidad o año nuevo. El nuevo préstamo lo utilizará para comprar productos de limpieza y artículos de cocina. La forma ambulante de vender les ayuda a tener mayor contacto con clientes potenciales y también a brindar una atención más precisa. Su meta actual, sin embargo, es adquirir un local para poder aumentar sus ventas y exhibir los bordados artesanales que realiza Yolanda para tener ingresos extras. 
   Los demás integrantes del grupo son: Raúl quien invertirá en artículos domésticos; Juana, en bisutería; María y Rubén, en productos de jarcería; María Esther en productos plásticos y Maribel, en ropa.
*La fotografía fue tomada en las escaleras del quiosco municipal, Yolanda es quien viste una playera rosa.
texts.en:
Galilea is the name of a group formed by happy and hard-working people coming from a small, peaceful community surrounded by vegetation. This name was chosen by its members, since it is the same as that of a little girl, the daughter of a member. It is worth mentioning that they have a great bond to their traditions, religious as well as popular, and on the holidays they spend time together in a friendly and even sisterly way.

Everyone affectionately calls Yolanda "Yola," since they think highly of her and have confidence in her because of her kind and dependable character. She is the mother of two daughters, one of whom is Galilea. They attend primary school and are her great motivation for continuing forward. For 12 years she has been working in commerce. Initially, she sold belts, but with time she found more favorable income in cleaning products, and since then she has not stopped. She and her husband coordinate between themselves to sell, acquire merchandise, and care for their little ones, for whom they make all this effort. "Generally we travel some days to obtain earnings, and we come back a little afterwards to rest and spend time with our daughters," she commented.

One of the seasons in which they obtain greater earnings is that of the end of the year, since many people look for items to make the Christmas or New Year's dinner. She will use the new loan to buy cleaning products and cooking items. Selling as street vendors helps them to have greater contact with potential customers and also to give them more specific attention. Their present goal, nevertheless, is to acquire a fixed location in order to be able to increase their sales and exhibit the artisanal embroideries that Yolanda does to have extra income.

The other members of the group are Raúl, who will invest in domestic articles; Juana, in costume jewelry; Maria and Rubén, in cleaning products; Maria Esther in plastic products; and Maribel, in clothing.

The photograph was taken on the steps of the municipal kiosk. Yoland is the one wearing a pink t-shirt.

loans.use: to buy cleaning products and kitchen items.

location.town: San Agustin Mextepec,San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Nuestra Esperanza Group

texts.es:
NUESTRA ESPERANZA ESTA CONFORMADA POR  DIES INTEGRANTES  MUJERES RESPONSABLES, MADRES SOLTERAS CON DIES HIJOS TODOS, SON ORIGINARIOS DEL SAUCE, LUGAR QUE ESTA UBICADO EN LA ZONA NORTE DE LA REGION, SE CARACTERIZA POR SER TRABAJADORA, RESPONSABLES, CON GANAS DE SUPERACION PERSONAL, LAMENTABLEMENTE POR FALTA DE RECURSOS ECONOMICOS NO PUDIERON ESTUDIAR Y SE VIERON EN LA NECESIDAD DE TRABAJAR PARA AYUADAR CON LOS GASTOS DE HOGAR.
GRACIAS A SUS GANAS DE SALIR ADELANTE LA CORDINADORA ES SILVIA Y TIENE POR ACTIVIDAD ECONONICA UNA PULPERIA  ES UNA PEQUENA TIENDA QUE VENDE PRODUCTOS COMESTIBLES EN CANTIDADES PEQUENAS COMO ARROZ, FRIJOLES, AZUCAR, LECHE, CUAJADA, QUESO, HUEVOS, FOSFOROS, JABON, JUGOS, GALLETAS, ETC, ELLA DEDICA UNAS DOCE HORAS DIARIAS OFRECIENDO PRODUCTOS COMESTIBLES PARA QUE EN UN FUTURO NO MUY LEJANO PUEDA OBTENER MEJORES INGRESOS NUESTRA ESPERANZA AGRADECE LA AYUDA QUE LOS INVERSIONISTAS KIVA LE BRINDAN A PERSONAS DE ESCASOS RECURSOS Y PAISES POBRE COMO ES NICARAGUA  PARA TENER UN MEDIO DE TRABAJO DIGNO.
texts.en:
Nuestra Esperanza is comprised of ten members, all of whom are responsible women, single mothers with ten children each. They live in El Sauce, located on the north of the region. They are characterized for being hard-working, responsible women with a desire of self-improvement. Unfortunately, due to a lack of financial resources, they were not able to go to school and they had to help out with the expenses of their households.

Thanks to her desire to get ahead in life, the group coordinator is Silvia. She has a small grocery store where she sells small quantities of products such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, curd, cheese, eggs, matches, soap, juice, cookies, etc. She works twelve hours a day offering her products and she hopes, in the near future, to be able to improve her income.

Nuestra Esperanza thanks the help the Kiva investors are giving to people with limited resources in poor countries like Nicaragua, which allow them to have a respectable job.

loans.use: invest in products such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, eggs, coffee, juice, cookies, etc.

loans.name: Iris Yamileth

texts.es: Iris es una mujer trabajadora que a sus 27 años de edad se gana la vida con su negocio de venta de pescado y diversidad de mariscos, actividad que realiza sobre la carretera que va hacia la playa, por lo que sus ventas son muy buenas. Ella vive con su compañero de vida y su hijo de 8 años de edad. Iris desea invertir en su negocio, ya que no cuenta con la liquidez económica necesaria solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: pescado, mariscos, cangrejos, para su venta esperando recibir el apoyo de este crédito.
texts.en:
Iris is a hard-working, 27-year-old woman who makes a living through her business selling fish and various shellfish. She works on the highway that goes toward the beach, so her sales are very good.

She lives with her life partner and her 8-year-old son.

Irish wants to invest in her business. Because she doesn't have the necessary economic liquidity, she is requesting a loan from FUSAI to invest in fish, shellfish, and crabs to sell. She is hoping to receive the support of this loan.

loans.use: to invest in fish, shellfish, and crab to sell

loans.name: Fiskani

texts.en:
Fiskani is a 31-year-old woman with a zest for life. She is looking to take on a new challenge that will also help support her family. Fiskani resides in a town called Zomba in the southern part of Malawi and she is looking to start running her own business as a Zoona mobile money transfer agent.

Fiskani aspires to become an independent individual who is fully capable of supporting her family. Currently, the economy in Malawi makes it difficult for young people to find gainful employment. This makes it difficult for Fiskani to support herself. She believes that becoming a Zoona agent will turn this situation around.

Fiskani has a certificate in Hotel Management and loves working with people. She would like to use that knowledge to make a success of running her own mobile money transfer business. She would like to use the revenue generated to improve her current standard of living. Fiskani would also like to help her community thrive by becoming a viable, trustworthy alternative in a country where banking is simply too expensive. She would like to achieve this by taking safe money transfer facilities to her community.

Fiskani has requested her first Kiva loan in order to procure her own trolley and a phone, which she can use to serve her customers. The loan will also provide Fiskani the funds needed to serve her customers. In a country where locals mainly send money for education fees, family maintenance and food purchases, this is a basic need. Zoona has done market research, and has found that the location in which Fiskani is looking to open her outlet would be ideal to serve people who need access to financial services. Fiskani thanks the Kiva lenders for believing in her.

loans.use: to procure a branded trolley and an internet-enabled phone as well as the funds needed to start running her own business.

loans.name: Pedro Antonio

texts.es: Pedro es un microempresario que habita en el municipio de Soledad en compañía de su familia, él es un cónyuge y  padre amoroso que vela por el bienestar de su familia y que entrega lo mejor de sí mismo al momento de elaborar las almojábanas de maíz, receta que le suministró un familiar hace veinte años y que en sus tiempos libres elaboraba e innovaba colocándole su toque personal.  Hace 12 años decidió emprender su negocio y pensó que este delicioso producto, el cual hace parte de la gastronomía de la Costa Caribe, podría comercializarse en tiendas de barrio al por menor, así que inició su primera producción y empezó a distribuir a diferentes tiendas de barrio, teniendo gran acogida. Pedro desea que su negocio sea más rentable y para ello comprará las materias primas e insumos al por mayor, garantizando menores costos y el beneficio de contar con todos materiales necesarios para su producción, proyecto que financiará con un credikiva por intermedio de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, recursos que invertirá en harina de maíz, queso, mantequilla, huevos y recipientes de vidrio. A futuro Pedro desea patentar su marca, abrir una fábrica y generar empleo a muchas más personas.
texts.en:
Pedro is a small business owner who lives in the municipality of Soledad with his family. He is a loving spouse and father who watches out for his family's well-being. He puts his best effort into making the corn and cheese bread (almojábanas) using the recipe originally given to him by a relative twenty years ago. In his spare time, he would make the recipe, adding personal touches. Twelve years ago he decided to start his business and he thought that this delicious product of the cuisine of Colombia's Caribbean coast could be sold in neighborhood retail stores. He started up production and began distributing to different neighborhood stores, which welcomed the product.

Pedro wants his business to be more profitable, so he will buy the ingredients and supplies at wholesale, guaranteeing lower costs and the benefit of having all the necessary materials for production. He will finance this project with a Kiva loan through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. He will invest these resources in corn flour, cheese, butter, eggs, and glass containers. In the future, Pedro wants to trademark his brand, open a factory, and create jobs for many more people.

loans.use: to invest in corn flour, cheese, butter, eggs, and glass containers.

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
Jorge, se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente siembra maíz y frijol, él vive junto a sus hijos y su compañera de vida, él comenta que se dedica a la agricultura desde hace 5 años, esta actividad le ha permitido poder obtener ingresos estables para poder sacar adelante a su familia.
Él solicita crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de abono, ya que de esa manera podra fortalecer mucho más los cultivos de granos básicos. Al invertir en la siembra de maíz y frijol espera que le dé mejores ganancias y por lo tanto su familia será la más beneficiada, ya que podrán tener una mejor calidad de vida.
Jorge sueña poder hacer de sus hijos unas personas útiles a la sociedad, de igual manera ser una persona reconocida en su lugar de residencia, y poder suplir todas las necesidades de su hogar.
texts.en:
Jorge works as a farmer; specifically, he grows corn and beans. He lives with his children and his life partner. He says that he has worked in farming for 5 years now. This job has enabled him to obtain a stable income in order to support his family.

He is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of fertilizer, so that he can strengthen his basic grain plants a lot more. By investing in the sowing of corn and beans, he hopes it will give him better earnings, and therefore his family will receive the most benefit and be able to have a better quality of life.

Jorge dreams of being able to make his children into people who are helpful to society, as well as being a well-known person in his area of residence. He dreams of being able to supply all his home's necessities.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer so that he can strengthen his grain plants much more

loans.name: Akua Amessiwoalo Segbedzi

texts.fr: Akua est une femme divorcée âgée de 58 ans résidante à Adidogomé. Ayant un enfant à charge, Akua est une marchande des tubercules d’ignames qu’elle s’approvisionne une fois par mois  au marché et le revend sur commande. Akua désire ce prêt pour commander des calebasses de tubercules d’ignames. Avec la marge bénéficiaire qui en résultera, Akua compte améliorer sa prestation de vente et pouvoir subvenir à ses besoins quotidiens puis à l’épanouissement de son enfant.
texts.en: Akua is a divorced 58-year old woman living in Adidogome. She has a dependent child. Akua sells yams, stocking up at the market once a month and selling on order. Akua would like to obtaint his loan in order to stock up on yams. Thanks to her resulting profit margin, she plans to improve her business and be able to provide for her daily expenses as well as for the well-being of her child.

loans.use: to buy two  calabashes of yams.

loans.name: Orostamo

texts.ru: Жительница района Хамадони. Ее зовут Оростамо.  Оростамо имеет двоих детей. Сыновья взрослые и самостоятельные. Старший сын занимается таксистом и помогает маме обеспечить семью. Младший сын вместе с Оростамо выращивает мелко рогатого скота. Оростамо 3 года занимается животноводством. Оростамо так много трудиться, чтобы зарабатывать обеспечить семью. Она сейчас хочет увеличить поголовья скота и расширить деятельность, по этой причине Оростамо обратилась за кредитом. Это кредит поможет ей сохранить деятельность и не потерять источник дохода.
texts.en:
This is Orostamo. She lives in the Hamadoni region. Orostamo has two children. Her sons are grown and independent. Her eldest son works as a taxi driver and helps provide for the household.  Orostamo's youngest son raises small livestock together with her. Orostamo has been raising liveestock for three years. She works very hard to provide for her family. 

At present she would like to increase her livestock headcount and expand her business, which is why she has applied for a loan. This loan will allow her to maintain her business and avoid losing a source of income.

loans.use: to buy small livestock and maintain her business.

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina, 24, lives in Morogoro district; she is married with one child. Zaina is a Camfed learner guide who volunteers, working with children in secondary school, teaching them life and problem solving skills to help them improve their learning.

Zaina has a clothing business: she sells women's and children's clothes. Zaina doesn’t have a shop: she sells her clothes from door to door. She is asking for a Kiva loan to buy her products in bulk to increase her profits. She will also use the loan to set a shop for her business.

Zaina plans to use the profit she will earn to pay for her child's school fees and help her family with healthcare. She has a dream of opening a big clothing shop.

loans.use: To buy her products in bulk to increase profit

loans.name: Anteh We 2 Group

texts.en:
This group is called "Anteh we 2" and is part of a process to eliminate poverty. The three women that make up the Anteh we 2, are a self-sacrificing group that want to overcome whatever situation they may find themselves in.

Rebecca is one of the members of the group and makes a living by selling rice, beans, fish, meat, chicken and other ingredients for food production. The effort she makes to improve herself to provide a better life for her family is worth emphasizing. Rebecca is grateful for the opportunity she has by being a part of this group.

She is asking for a loan to buy food items for sale, such as fish, rice, beans, and so forth. This will allow her to boost her business plan and help to improve her income.

loans.use: to buy food items for sale, such as fish, rice, beans and so forth.

loans.name: Ejido De Mayorazgo Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad pequeña del Estado de México donde habitan personas muy amables y  trabajadoras se integró un grupo llamado Ejido de Mayorazgo. Las integrantes se dedican, entre otras cosas, a la cría de animales además del cultivo de maíz. Cabe mencionar que en dicha comunidad se lleva a cabo una gran celebración a propósito del día muertos donde acostumbran colocar las ofrendas dentro de sus casas y visitar los panteones para conmemorar a sus seres fallecidos. Por otro lado están por cosechar el maíz, producto del trabajo de todo un año; con él realizan tortillas, atoles, tamales y otros productos derivados.
   Josefina es una de las integrantes más amables y trabajadoras del grupo la cual siempre está comprometida con el bienestar de su familia. Doña Jose, como le dicen de cariño sus allegados, desde hace un año abrió una cocina económica que no es otra cosa sino un lugar en donde los clientes pueden degustar platillos con el sazón característico del hogar. “Mi sueño siempre fue  tener un negocio propio para ayudar a mi esposo con los gastos del hogar" comentó muy entusiasmada Jose quien anteriormente tenía una tienda de abarrotes que tuvo que cerrar por causas de fuerza mayor.
   Actualmente está muy contenta ya que su negocio funciona según lo esperado y con la ayuda del préstamo podría comprar verdura, aceites, arroz, frijoles etc. para continuar con la mejor variedad y el mejor precio. Sus ganancias le ayudan, sobretodo, a solventar los gastos de su hogar y cumplir en tiempo y forma con el préstamo solicitado. Se siente muy confiada pues mantiene clientes seguros y sus ingresos son atractivos, su meta es hacer aumentar su producción para ahorrar en un fondo para cuando desee retirarse. 
   Los demás integrantes del grupo son Carolina quien invertiría en fruta; Janeth, Ma. Elidia y Don Federico, en ovejas y en una tienda de abarrotes.
*La fotografía fue tomada en las escaleras del quiosco municipal, Doña Jose es quien porta el mandil color azul.
texts.en:
In a small community in the state of Mexico, where very friendly and hard working people live, a group named Ejido de Mayorazgo was formed. The members work in animal husbandry and in growing corn, among other things. It is worth mentioning that his community holds a great celebration for the Día de los Muertos (Day of the Dead), where people customarily leave offerings in their homes, and visit the cemeteries to commemorate their loved ones who have passed away.

On the other hand, they are about to harvest their corn, a product that requires year-round work. With corn, they make tortillas, atoles (traditional corn-based drinks), tamales and other products. 

Josefina is one of nicest and most hard working members of the group, and is always committed to her family's well-being. "Doña Jose", as her relatives affectionately call her, opened an informal restaurant one year ago. This is nothing but a place where her customers can sample dishes with home made flavors. 

"My dream has always been to have my own business to help my husband with household expenses", said a very enthusiastic Josefina. Before, she had a small grocery store that she had to close due to circumstances beyond her control. Now, she is very pleased that her business is working as she had hoped. With the help of this loan, she can buy vegetables, cooking oil, rice, beans, etc., to continue with the best variety and best price. Her earnings will help her, above all, to meet household expenses and repay her loan in full and on time.

She feels very confident, as she maintains regular customers and her income is good. Her goal is to grow her business to build a savings fund for retirement.

The other members of the group are Carolina who will invest in fruit; Janeth, Maria Elidia and Federico, who will invest in sheep and in a small grocery store.

* The photograph was taken at the steps of the city kiosk. Josefina is the one wearing the blue apron.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, cooking oil, rice, soups, etc.

loans.name: Lucky

texts.en:
Lucky is a 26-year-old young man who resides in Blantyre, Malawi. He is the youngest in a family of five and is looking to start running his own business, like his father whom he looks up to. Lucky has a passion for business. His biggest dream is to own and run his own business as this would not only create an employment opportunity for him but also honor his father, the man who inspired him to make a go of becoming an entrepreneur.

Lucky has a certificate in Accounting and he would like to use that knowledge to make a success of running his own mobile money transfer business. He would like to use the revenue generated to provide for his family.

Lucky is excited to bring safe money transfer facilities to his community. People in Blantyre mainly send money for education fees, family maintenance and food purchases; this is a basic need. When Lucky receives this loan, he will be able to purchase a branded trolley and an internet-enabled phone which he will use to serve his customers.

Lucky's dream is to run a successful business. He sees this loan as a life changing opportunity.

loans.use: to procure a branded trolley and an internet-enabled phone as well as the funds needed to make the actual transactions so that he can start running his own business.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
With his first loan, Ibrahim was able to decrease his costs by getting a new ladder instead of renting one. He was happy to see his monthly savings increase as he is still engaged and preparing to start his own family and move into his own house. For the moment, he still lives with his mother and his brothers both still work.

Ibrahim's business has been constantly improving since the first loan. He now has an apprentice helping him in his projects. Today, Ibrahim is asking for a 2,569,000 Lebanese pounds loan from Kiva partner Ibdaa. This time, he will be using the loan to buy quantities of paint. He also needs to upgrade some of his painting tools. He hopes that with this loan his business will continue to improve as well as his family's well-being.

loans.use: to buy quantities of paint and renew part of his equipment kit

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en:
Sifa, 31, lives in Morogoro with her husband and her family. She works as a Camfed learner guide in her nearby secondary school, where she teaches life skills to students.

Sifa is a tailor. She is requesting a second Kiva loan to expand her business by buying varieties of fabrics to sew women's clothes. The profit will help Sifa buy basic needs like clothes and decent meals for her family

loans.use: To buy fabrics for her tailoring business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 31 years old and currently living with her husband and her child in Morogoro district. She is a Camfed core trainer who works with learner guides; she mentors and provides technical support to them when they are working with youth in schools.

Grace runs a mobile money business. She is requesting a Kiva loan to invest in her business to boost the running capital. She plans to use the profit she will earn to help her siblings with their school contributions and will also help vulnerable children.

loans.use: to increase her business liquidity for her mobile money service.

loans.name: Aneeshah

texts.en:
Aneeshah is an emerging entrepreneur. She is 22 years old and has two siblings. She is excited to start running her own business and is requesting a loan in order to have the capital needed to start running the business as a mobile money transfer agent in Malawi’s Nsanje district.

Aneeshah was supported through school by an Islamic institution because her family could not afford to support her through school financially. Through her hard work, she went on to obtain a certificate in journalism and loves working with people. She would like to use that skill to make a success of running her own mobile money transfer business.

She would like to use the revenue generated to improve her current standard of living.

Aneeshah would also like to help her community by taking safe money transfer facilities to her community, and when the business grows, she hopes to employ people in her community.

This loan will provide the start-up capital needed to set up her own business in her hometown of Nsanje. She thanks the Kiva lenders for supporting her.

loans.use: to purchase a branded trolley and an Internet enabled phone, as well as provide the funds needed to make the transactions so that she can start running her own business.

loans.name: Bi Nyomo 3 Group

texts.en:
The group Bi Nyomo 3 is located in Teshie, Accra, Ghana, and is a group of three very active women who, above all, want to better their quality of life. They are selling fish, tuna and scarves.

Rhoda is 40 years old and married with six children, all in the elementary level of education. She is a member of the Bi Nyomo 3 group and is very excited to begin her 11th loan cycle with ID-Ghana, Teshie branch.

Rhoda sells fish. Her business income is able only to pay for the costs of maintaining her home and supporting her husband for the payment of school fees.

She is requesting a new loan in order to buy more fish to cover all of her customers' demands because without more investment capital, she feels that her own income is not sufficient.

Besides the loans, Rhoda and the other members of Bi Nyomo 3 also benefit from a combination of loans and education (training). The loan officer and the training officer share timely and useful information with the members on a variety of subjects like health, hygiene and nutrition, as well as self-esteem and violence against women. The members learn about effective business management practices and customer service, as well as gain essential knowledge about business planning, customer service, marketing and pricing. All of these subjects help them better their lives both economically and developmentally.

loans.use: to buy more fish to cover all of her customers' demands.

loans.name: Kes Pa Nou (Mc)

texts.en:
Marie-Claudette is living in Carrefour Feuilles, a suburb in the south of Port-au-Prince. Carrefour-Feuilles is one of the numerous poor neighborhoods in the capital. The 2010 earthquake left thousands dead in that area. Marie-Claudette's house had some repairable splits. Since then, she has been earning her living with a small grocery store that provides food and schooling for all her five children.

Marie-Claudette, like many Zafen borrowers, has much courage to fight against poverty. That's why she does not give up strengthening 25 other women in her community. Today, she is in the committee board of a group. She is looking for a loan to buy food and home products in bulk to retail during Christmas.

Portrayed from left to right are Maxcene (advisor), Cherestal (treasurer), Rosalie (secretary), Marie-Claudette (leader) and Alva (treasurer).

loans.use: to buy food and home products to retail during Christmas.

loans.name: Houssam

texts.en:
Houssam is a 47-year-old Palestinian who owns a coffee shop in a Palestinian refugee camp located in North Lebanon.

He is married and lives in the same camp with his wife and two daughters. His two daughters recently graduated from school and started going to university.

Five years ago, Houssam decided to use his savings and start a new concept inside the camp, selling refreshments and coffee from his van. He sells all types of fresh juice and coffee to his customers all day long, which is also an opportunity to get to know them and exchange stories.

The business has been going better than Houssam expected, and his customers have been increasing fast.

He is asking for a 3,083,000 Lebanese pounds loan for the first time from Kiva partner Ibdaa. This loan will help him increase his income by getting a new coffee machine as well as a set of table and chairs. As such, he will be able to serve more customers and hopefully boost his business enough to start providing the youth of his neighborhood with employment opportunities.

loans.use: to buy a new espresso machine.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary (22) is hardworking. She volunteers her time as a Camfed Learner Guide, teaching life skills to students at the local secondary school. Through her lessons, Mary encourages students to find their own strengths and to think about how to lead a better life.

To earn a living, Mary runs a palm oil business. She is requesting a second Kiva loan to buy palms in bulk, and the profit will be used to invest in a bicycle business she has just started. The profit generated will also help her cater for her family needs.

loans.use: to buy more palms in bulk to produce more palm oil.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 25-year-old entrepreneur; She is currently living with her child and her husband in Kilombero district. She is volunteering as a health activist; she gives time each week to deliver programs in communities to provide information on sanitation, infant care, HIV/AIDS, and many other health-related topics.

Though she currently doesn't have her own business, Elizabeth is requesting a Kiva loan to start a beauty salon. She plans to use the profit she will earn to reinvest in her business to help it grow and to support her parents with medical care.

loans.use: to start a beauty salon business.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a Palestinian taxi driver. He has been earning his living from working in North Lebanon for 17 years. However, he decided to get his own car in 2009 in order to save the renting costs.

He is 53 years old and lives with his wife and their four children, two daughters and two sons, in the refugee camp located in North Lebanon. Both his sons are employees, and his daughters are pursuing a university degree.

His wife being unemployed, Ibrahim works hard to provide the family with decent living conditions with the support of his sons. He has a little experience working in gypsum, which allows him to take projects on the side for extra income.

Ibrahim needs to complete some maintenance work on his car. That is why he is asking for a 1,543,992 Lebanese pounds loan from Kiva partner Ibdaa. Performing the maintenance work will protect him from eventual breakdowns that could affect his income and ability to cover his household's expenses in a considerable way.

loans.use: to complete needed maintenance work on his car.

loans.name: Rakma

texts.en:
Rakma is a hardworking, 19-year-old woman living in Lilongwe, the capital city of Malawi. She would like to set up her own business as a mobile money transfer agent so that she can provide a service to people who need to access financial services.

Rakma is the breadwinner in a family of four. Her dream is to run her own business so that she can provide the basic needs for her family. Rakma’s challenge is that she does not have the capital needed to start running her own business. She is excited about the opportunity to be connected to Kiva lenders, as she sees this as an opportunity to change her life and that of her family.

With this loan, Rakma will be able to purchase a trading trolley which she will set up outside one of the farmer’s shops in Mangochi. Rakma will also use this loan to purchase a web-enabled phone, which she will use to make the actual transactions. The loan will also provide Rakma with the float needed to serve her customers.

Rakama’s dream is to influence some of the young people in her family to become entrepreneurs like her. She is hopeful that this will improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to procure a branded trolley and an Internet-enabled phone, as well as the funds needed to make the actual transactions so that she can start running her own business.

loans.name: Dahiru

texts.en:
Dahiru is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Dahiru has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, which is 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Dahiru would have had to sell his maize at harvest time, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, in order to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Dahiru can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest time.

As a Babban Gona member, Dahiru will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000 per hectare of land. He is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the lives of his children and family, and he looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Bitrus

texts.en:
Bitrus is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Bitrus has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Bitrus would have had to sell his maize at harvest time, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, in order to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Bitrus can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest time.

As a Babban Gona member, Bitrus will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. He is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the lives of his children and family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en:
Ayuba is a maize farmer from Nakaura village. As a Babban Gona member, Ayuba is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, which is 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Ayuba would have had to sell his maize at harvest time, when the price of maize is at its lowest, in order to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member, he can store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a period later on in the season, when he can obtain the best price for it at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest time.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Ayuba no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, he hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thus eliminating the pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Cruz Angel

texts.es: Cruz tiene 47 años de edad en los cuales siempre ha mostrado su tenacidad, por lo que desde hace 8 años se dedica a la venta de pescado de forma ambulante, además buscando obtener mejores ingresos vende productos de belleza por catálogo. Ella vive con su compañero de vida y sus dos hijas de 12 y 11 años de edad  a las que apoya para que estudien, ya que ella desea que tengan una mejor calidad de vida. Cruz desea invertir en su negocio de venta de pescado, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: pescado, mariscos, cangrejos, entre otros necesarios para surtir su mercadería y aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en: Cruz is 47 years old and has always shown tenacity, which is why eight years ago she started making a living selling fish on the street as well as looking to earn extra income selling beauty products via catalog. Cruz lives with her husband and their two daughters, ages 12 and 11, whose education she is supporting so they can have a better quality of life. Cruz wants to invest in her fish-selling business, which is why she is requesting a loan to purchase fish, seafood, crab and other necessities to increase her supplies and improve her sales.

loans.use: to purchase fish, seafood, crabs, and other necessities to increase her supplies and improve her sales.

loans.name: Balbino De Jesus

texts.es:
Balbino, es un hombre trabajador que con el crédito anterior fortaleció la tienda y se ha mantenido trabajando en el campo, con lo que ha logrado salir adelante con su situación económica que estaba atravesando, por lo tanto pudo continuar con el sostenimiento de su familia. Actualmente el convive con su compañera de vida y su pequeño hijo de 13 meses.
Balbino solicita nuevamente un crédito para poderlo invertir en la compra de insumos agrícolas para mejorar sus cultivos y eliminar la maleza del terreno, de esa manera continuar alimentando a su grupo familiar y satisfaciendo las necesidades de sus clientes.
texts.en: Balbino is a hardworking man who strengthened his store with the previous loan. He continues working on the land and has been able to make headway with his financial situation and provide for his family. He lives with his wife and their young son of 13 months. Balbino is again requesting a loan to purchase farming supplies to improve his crops and rid his land of weeds, and in this way he can continue feeding his family and meeting his customers' needs.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies to improve his crops and rid his land of weeds

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Through the first loan, Mwanaidi was able to set up the shop, and the profit has enabled her to send her son and her brother to a good school and to provide health care for her parents and family.

Mwanaidi is now requesting a second Kiva loan to increase the electronic appliances in her shop. She will use the profit she earns to continue to boost her business and to provide her family with a good standard of living.

loans.use: to buy television sets, fans and radios to continue her electrical appliance business.

loans.name: Sirajo

texts.en:
Sirajo is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Sirajo has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, which is 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Sirajo would have had to sell his maize at harvest time, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, in order to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Sirajo can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest time.

As a Babban Gona member, Sirajo will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. He is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the lives of his children and family, and he looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thus eliminating the pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras De Marquez Group

texts.es: Susan es conviviente madre de dos hijos de ocho y cinco años de edad vive con su esposo sus dos hijos,su hermana su cuñado y su sobrina, ella se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza en su casa desde hace tres años, atiende a 10 clientes diarios, les brinda limpieza de cutis  gratis para que la gente pruebe las cremas que vende y así tiene mayor venta,el dinero del préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería como perfumes,cremas cosméticos ya que comprando por mayor cantidad es mayor el descuento y así puede abastecer a sus clientes mas rápido. Susan dice: me siento muy contenta de poder contar con la ayuda de los inversionistas Kiva  por que gracias a ellos no podría lograr mis metas.
texts.en: Susan is a mother of two children, ages 8 and 5, and lives with her husband, her kids, her sister, her brother-in-law and her niece. She has made a living selling beauty products from her home for the past three years, tending to 10 customers a day. She gives them a free facial so they can sample the creams she sells and in this way improves her sales. She plans to use the loan to purchase supplies such as perfumes and cosmetic creams in large quantities to get a bigger discount so she can stock up for her customers more quickly. Susan says, "I feel very content to be able to count on the help of Kiva lenders, because without them I would not be able to achieve my goals."

loans.use: to purchase perfumes, makeup and creams.

loans.name: Combattant La Grenade

texts.en:
Missalene lives in Carrefour, a known neighborhood where 20,000 rural people are located. According to state statistics, that place has more than 58% of the women living in poverty. Missalene is one of them. However, she is fighting to improve her living. To achieve that, she is involved in a group of 30 people, mostly women. She helps them with savings.

Today she is applying for a loan to purchase beans to retail. With that loan, each woman will generate at least $4 per sack daily. Apart from that, Missalene will encourage the women to attend a literacy program and other non-financial services from Zafen.

Pictured from left to right are Robenson (advisor), Angela (treasurer), Yolene with the white blouse is the secretary, Rosana (deputy treasurer) and Missalene dressed with a red blouse (far right).

loans.use: to purchase 24 sacks of beans to sell
